posts.cooked:
Our setup is a MK4 NEO swerve motor with a absolute CANCoder connected to a Spark Max motor controller.

We are coding this in Java. On boot up, how does the robot know that the wheels are pointing in the same direction?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: It doesn’t.  That’s the point of having an absolute sensor like the cancoder. Figure out what angle your modules are actually at using the can coder then apply that to the motor encoders.
We set values when the wheels are straight and we want to save those values and applie those instead on having them set to 0.

You would typically save those values in a Constants file and then take the difference between them and the CANCoder on startup.

e.g. If you know the module is straight ahead when the CANCoder returns 15 degrees and the CANCoder returns 45 degrees on startup then you know the module is 30 degrees off of center.
We do that but our swerve modules get out of sync after a few seconds of driving then we have to  get new values.

You need to put the CANCoders into absolute mode.

Magnet Placement: Using the CANCoder User’s Guide, verify that magnet placement is correct for the CANCoder. Phoenix Tuner: Open Phoenix tuner and use the Self-test Snapshot feature to confirm valu...

Hollisms:

CANCoders into absolute mode.

We tried to set the the Sensor Initialization Strategy to BootToAbsValue in Phoenix Tuner but when the robot rebooted in didn’t save and went back to BootToZero.
You should set it in code:

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
There is a bug in the display or get of the init strategy from at least last year which apparently CTRE hasn’t fixed yet (note our comment in code from last year). In our code we use degrees. I think I pasted all the pertinent code below but I can’t guarantee it - it’s been over a year since I looked at this.

Our constants file with magnet angles when wheels are straight ahead assuming 360 degrees - don’t get any 180 degrees reversed. These are the values for turnEncoderOffset above

get the position with

Use the Phoenix Tuner to figure out all this then put the values you want to use in code like the above. Don’t trust the device memory to be right.
